Presumably large format camera, 2-3 stop ambient underexposure with a flash fill, gelled with a warming filter and either umbrella or panel diffused, 45 degrees camera left, on a low depth of field.  Most 4x5 large formats only go to f/5.6 so this could be modified or the subject is far enough away from any other scenery to give the impression of a shallower scene.

taellinuaichi: The photographer for this image was Alfred T. Palmer. He worked for the Office of War Information News Bureau. Interestingly, in a 1990 interview, Palmer was actually somewhat critical of some of the Depression-era photographs produced by the Farm Security Administration (FSA). Speaking of Roy Stryker, who had headed the FSA unit for which Dorothea Lange worked and who later moved over to head an OWI photo unit, Palmer said, “He [Stryker] considered me a ‘glamour photographer’ who had to be taught the facts of life, but I felt that what he did at the FSA was manipulation—encouraging the photographers to show the worst conditions. I didn’t carry a skull on the back of my car to plant in the foreground of a picture to make a point. I didn’t light a sharecropper’s shack in such a way as to make it look as stark as possible. I believed in looking at the things in a helpful and encouraging manner.” (quoted in Nicholas Natanson, The Black Image in the New Deal: The Politics of FSA Photography (Knoxville: The University of Tennessee Press, 1992), 257-258. ) Palmer also did maritime photography - a listing for materials by him appears here: http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=tf4j49n761&doc.view=items&item.position=101&brand=oac. He apparently shot motion pictures, as well. There is a listing for a collection of his film work on this page: http://www.nps.gov/archive/safr/local/safrhdd.html.

A spectacular image, just goes to show the process of photography was essentally perfected by this time. The tools of the trade were a bit more tempermental but in the hand of the right professional they could yield an image as good or perhaps even better that we can today. My father shot alot of Kodak transparency film using his old Canon back in the 60's and the quality is beyond compare. Every time I look at them it amazes me, they could have been taken yesterday. In the digital age it easy to forget the chemical process and the beautiful images recorded for over  the last 150 years, I just dont think digital cameras are capable of this life like realism, at least not yet.

the original m3 was changed by the british who removed the copula on top of the turret and enlarged the turret to take a radio.the british called these the grant.they later took delivery of the original version calling it the lee.the m3 in the picture have their copula so must asume to be lees.

Look carefully at the tank hulls. The first and third M3's have a more angular riveted hull than the second one which MIGHT be cast.  I've never seen one like the second one, but I do know that the Grant and Lee names (from the British) were due to production models.  The whole M3 medium series were an interim design that was rushed into production just to get something into the hands of the troops.

The first and second M4's also have a more angular hull of welded plates than the third one which has a rounded cast hull.   These were production variations from different plants, but all M4's were named Shermans.  It was the British who originally started the practice of naming US tanks after our generals.  Then we continued the practice with Pershing, Patton, Sheridan, and Abrams.
You're right. By the way I was on the "Sheridan"!
the cast hull version has the designation m3a1.and was built by the firm baldwin and lima.i might be wrong but i don,t think they originally made tanks but were an engineering firm.

I was very often thinking why I have different feeling from these very old photographs.. They usually have very low depth of field, which is understandable, but they also have amazing space.. I realized it when I was looking to the Library of Congress sets.. Almost all pictures have slightly shorter focus (closer to the camera). Notice that the focus is to the grass before tank, and not to the tank itself. Today's practice is to focus directly to the point of interest (eyes in the portrait photography, tank turret in this case..)

The combination of the Garand and the dishpan helmet puts this photo in 1940 (unlikely), 1941 (most likely) or 1942 (unlikely).  The Garand debuted in the late 1930s and some Army infantry regiments were fully equipped with it by 1940.  The M1 Helmet, on the other hand, did not enter service until 1941.  Photos show some Army units embarking for overseas (Iceland?) with the old dishpans.

The insignia worn on the soldier's cap identifies him as a member of the 244th Coast Artillery Regiment.  The 244th, a tractor-drawn 155 mm cannon unit, had been a unit of the New York National Guard.  It was one of the first Guard units called into federal service in September 1940.  Some elements of the 244th remained in the Fort Story area (actually Camp Pendelton, about 10 miles south of the Fort) through May of 1942.

I'm not exactly sure, but  I think this is the airdock that Goodyear currently uses to house their blimps.

No its not.  It is now owned by Lockheed Martin who is building a high altitude airship for the military.  
Goodyear built a few dirigible blimps here in the thirties and then used it to build blimps during WWII.

Goodyear's blimp hanger is at Wingfoot Lake in Springfield Township, Ohio  - The 'Spirit of Goodyear' is based there.
It was said that the Airdock has it's own weather. Apparently it gets (or got) so humid, it felt like it was raining on you if you were inside.

This was the hangar were the airships "Akron" and "Macon" were built, by the Zeppelin/Goodyear Corporation. "Akron" and "Macon" were some of the largest flying machines ever built, just slightly smaller than the Zeppelins "Hindenburg" and "Graf Zeppelin II", very large, over 700ft long, and all built on a rigid frame design. The biggest difference between "Akron" and "Macon" and the Zepps, the Goodyear ships where floated with non-flammable Helium.

I worked there when the Chicago Board of Education was headquartered in those buildings in the early 90s.

This is at  about 1735 to about 1800 West Pershing Road from Hermitage to Wolcott Ave.  This is the South side of the building. (6 stories tall, two subbasements, built in 1916).  Used in WWII as a food depot.  Later used as grave storage.  During the 1950s and 1960s it was the 5th Army headquarters used to teach meat inspectors (this is just west and north of the Chicago stockyards area), also military police and two National Guard units.  (Comment offered by National Book Festival attendee who used to live across the street from this facility.)

In this picture I am pretty sure we are looking at the building from the North side, if you look at aerial photos you can see that the buildings are arranged F-E-D-C-B-A. Here are a couple of links so you can see what it looks like today: Google Street View Live Bird's Eye View

Something about that caption doesn't quite ring true.  The dimensions and near-center mount are consistent with the *barrel* of an M2A1 or M101 howitzer.  Note that the left end is turned down, which is characteristic of the breach end of the weapon.  She's using a micrometer to check a boss or flange of the outer diameter near the center mounting point, which is already greater than the roughly 4" ID of the barrel.  No "cutters" are evident, so there's no way one could be inserted *into* the barrel.  The castellated sleeve is probably internally threaded and engages the external threads seen on the barrel directly behind her.
inspector23,  Photographers are not engineers.
I've found in military history research that many anomalies and aberrations occur between the photograph and the caption.  "Kurtz" said it best - "Photographers are not engineers".

Some rather odd tags...

The aircraft shown is a Consolidated PBY patrol bomber. The "louvers" at the front of the aircraft are actually a Venetian blind that covers a transparent observer's window. The blinds helped to protect the window from seawater damage, and were opened in flight. The "landing gear" on this aircraft are actually "beaching gear," which were attached to the aircraft after landing on the water so that it could taxi up a ramp onto the shore. Later models of the PBY had retractable landing gear and could land or takeoff on runways as well as on the water.

My mistake! There is masking tape along the edge of the star! If you look closely at the largest image, you'll see light beige strips where the white meets the navy blue background. The tape is most visible at the two points of the star in the foreground. It runs onto the surrounding yellow color. 

My guess is that they painted a white circle first, then added the dark blue to create the star, but that would have been pretty complicated. Easier to paint the white on top of the blue, but how could it cover so well?

PBY-5A  (patrol bomber consolidated aircraft co.), October 1941 - January 1945, Hydraulically-actuated, retractable tricycle landing gear for amphibious operation. Introduced tail gun position, replaced bow single gun position with bow "eyeball" turret equipped with twin .30 machine guns (some later units), improved armor, self-sealing fuel tanks. 
Prior to the PBY-5, PBY 1, 2, 3 & 4's were true Seaplane's, designed & equipped only for water landing's & takeoff's.
The name of Catalina I, IA, IB, II, IIA, IIIA, IVA, IVB & VI, was used only by the British Commonwealth, though later adopted by everyone else after the war. 
USN & USCG Aviation Crews called the PBY's either "Cats" (day) or "Black Cats" (night) for Combat Missions or "Dumbo" for Air-Sea Rescue Missions.
USAAC's designation for the PBY was, OA-10, OA-10A, & OA-10B & GST by the Soviets.

At Brackenridge, four electric arc furnaces melt stainless and other specialty materials for subsequent refining in a 125-ton argon-oxygen decarburization (AOD) vessel which feeds a continuous caster. Slabs and other specialty steel ingots are hot rolled on a six-stand hot strip mill for shipment to other plants. Brackenridge also finishes certain stainless steel, silicon electrical steel and other specialty alloy sheet and strip.

This EMD FT of Santa Fe's 100 class were the very first batch of road freight diesels delivered in 1941.  AT&SF would eventually get 80 four unit sets of these first generation diesels and run them into the early to mid-1960's.  During WWII these locos were used mainly from Winslow AZ to points west in order to reduce water consumption in the desert.  They finished up their service in the less demanding Texas Gulf Coast where my grandfather was a Roadmaster in those days.  Childhood memories!  

Notice the cream yellow color of what is now known as the "catwhisker" paint scheme.  In the mid-1950's theis paint scheme was replaced by the "cigar band" scheme which had a darker chrome yellow.  The Santa Fe really maintained their engines well including keeping them clean.

#103 shown here was part of the first four sets of FT engines that ATSF purchased from EMD (General Motors) in January 1941. Units #100-104 each consisted of a cab lead engine, two cabless boosters and a trailing cab unit (an "LABC" configuration). A total of 320 FT units were acquired by August 1945. These were used primarily in CA and AZ resulting in total dieselization of "through" freight trains (Winslow, San Bernardino, Bakersfield) when this great photo was taken. After the war, the #103 set was moved to the Argentine-Corwith freight pool on the Illinois-Missouri division of the ATSF (KC-Chicago). #103 lasted until 1960-61 when it was traded back to EMD for a new road switcher. The early nose paint scheme shown here only existed on the #100-104 units. The red striping and SF shield were replaced by the classis yellow "cigar-band" used on all later blue FT/F3/F7 and ATSF passenger engines. www.shorpy.com/node/1747
I do not recall these colors on the Santa Fe. Excellent photo, nonetheless and I like this early style of diesel.

Of the streamliners in the back, the one with the prominent nose grille is one of M-10003 through M-10006, the pioneer streamlined trainsets built by Pullman-Standard with motive power equipment by General Motors' Electro-Motive. Partly hidden at the right is one of the EMD E2 locomotives, while the other locomotive, unobscured, is an EMD E6. All of these were jointly owned and operated by the C&NW and the Union Pacific.

The streamliners appear to be one of the M-10003–6 trainsets, one of the E2 locomotives, and one of the later E6 locomotives. All were joint ownership between the C&NW, the Union Pacific, and (in the case of the City of San Francisco trains) the Southern Pacific.

Is there a corner of N and Union Street in DC?

The corner in question is now the West end of N St. SW , at roughly 38.874676,-77.018784 (found using Google Maps). What used to be Union St. ran perpendicular to that point between M and O Streets. From the satellite images, it doesn't look like any of the buildings remain.

Anyone know what that new development is?
Here's the present day satellite photo.

The area is currently occupied by condos and apartment buildings, none of which are architecturally noteworthy or distinguished.  Arena Stage is also located in the general vicinty.  Southwest Washington was once alive with people and streetlife.  The urban "renewal" of the 1950s and 60s turned the area into a clean but sterile urban wasteland.

Just a footnote: Surname was Klonis which was changed to Collins, (americanized), once he arrived from Greece.

John P Collins was my grandfather. I grew "on the farm". It made many transformation over the years with many additions and most of the 'old' buildings torn down. My mother, his daughter , is 89 and living in Jupiter, Fl. The farm was sold probably  30 years ago. By the way, he was not a farmer in Greece. He was studying at a monastery to become a Greek Orthodox priest but was drafted into the army to serve in the Greek-Turkish War where he was wounded. He came to the US through Ellis Island when he was in his teens. He changed his name because it was easier to get a job if your name was Irish sounding. He spoke no English when he arrived and had only ten dollars to his name when he arrived. He was sponsered by a family in Taunton and that is how he came to settle there.  He was quite an individual, a real entrepreneur and owned many different businesses, including a store and a junk yard.
Thank you for the photos. They brought back a flood of old memories and I will show my mother the site when she visits me.

I am from Cincinnati, and have so often tried to imagine the faces of people who inhabited the city in the past, from the crucial time of the Underground Railroad onward. This picture is extremely powerful, and I am so glad it has been saved.

I'm not sure the point of adding yet another comment on the title, but personally, I LOVE the title. It is a piece of history. I understand that the currents of history colour the subtext of the word "negro" in a negative way, but the contemporary subtext of the word had no negative connotation. Some folks want to toe the line between preserving history and placating today's overly-sensitive masses by suggesting that "back then, they didn't know any better". But it is not the photographer or his contemporaries that didn't know better: it's WE who don't know any better--the degree to which we've coddled and insulated ourselves against any objection anyone might raise anywhere about anything that is deemed offensive for whatever reason. Let us remember that in arguably the most stirring example of rhetoric for the equality of races in America, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., used the word "negro" fifteen times to describe his own people. Are we to assume that Dr. King was ignorant or didn't know any better? That he was one given to submitting to the whims of the time, even if he knew it was degrading? The term was NOT degrading, but simply descriptive. Its degrading connotation is an after taste of decades of iniquity and struggle. I expect my viewpoint to be lent little credence, uninformed as it is by the necessity of personal experience, but: if I were descended from this spirited, egregiously wronged, but ultimately triumphant lineage, I'd think I'd want to embrace such a term as "negro", if only to invoke the power of continuity, history, solidarity, and oneness: uniting each new victory in an ongoing struggle to the trials from which it was born. I understand the desire to close ugly chapters of our past, and adopting new lexicon is one means of doing that. But I think zealously whitewashing those things which are reminders of past iniquities, when the reminders themselves are innocuous, is in its own way one more form of binding and fragmenting a truly beautiful people whose whole story is incomparably rich and deserving of our entire attention and respect, not this piecemeal selective memory that passes for sensitivity. -- Seen on my Flickr home page. Negro as defined in Wikipedia is actually pretty informative:
Negro is a term referring to people of Black ancestry. Prior to the shift in the lexicon of American and worldwide classification of race and ethnicity in the late 1960s, the appellation was accepted as a normal neutral formal term both by those of Black African descent as well as non-African blacks. Now it is often considered an ethnic slur although the term is considered archaic and is not common as a racist slur. The term is still used in some contexts for historical reasons such as in the name of the United Negro College Fund. "Negro" means "black" in Spanish, Portuguese, and ancient Italian - all of which derive from the Latin niger (i.e. "black").
Seems obvious this is an appropriate historical context, no? By the way, I find the photo both technically and emotionally extremely compelling. I wonder if this man is still alive, and what his story would be.

The title fits the photograph-- as others have mentioned, it's a product of its time. In any case, the word "Negro" wasn't considered derogatory in its day.

While I understand people's comments questioning the need to put a qualifier to designate a person's color, doing so would be counterproductive, in some ways. The "default" in the U.S. is "white" (and I'm speaking as a minority here, so this is an issue that affects me daily), so attempts to not address race at all in some ways cover over the issue-- and so we're left with the "default" of the same majority viewpoints. I specifically found this photograph because I wanted to find photographs that documented African-American life in the mid 20th century. If no "color" label had been added, it would have been lost in the sea of photographs documenting white America—which seem to be the majority of the photographs in the Commons.

Yet another comment about the title: When I was a boy in the Sixties, the correct thing to call African-Americans was "Negro." To us it brought forth images of Martin Luther King and the struggle for civil rights. It brought forth visions of courageous young men and women sitting with dignity at a lunch counter in the South, waiting to be served and ignoring the terrible hatred being thrown at them by the racist population. In my mind it described somebody that was very admirable. 

I think the word belongs in the title because in his eyes you can see some of the sorrow, and yet also the dignity and strength that led his people through the terrible persecution of Jim Crow, through the civil rights struggle and all the way to President Obama. Maybe this boy sat at a lunch counter or braved the dogs and fire hoses in Alabama as a young man, and voted for Obama as a senior citizen.

My name is Dani Atkins and I am one of 4 surviving children of Ronald Edward Atkins and Clancyna Marie Atkins. On January 26, 2008 my father was killed in a tragic car accident that took place only 2 minutes away from my home. My parents had been married for 30 years at the time of the accident without separation. As I have been assisting my mother with putting together various lawsuits and claims against several different persons, insurance companies, and even the Los Angeles Police Department regarding several acts of negligence and dishonor surrounding my fathers death, I have come across a disturbing piece of information that I, being a 24 year old African American person am appauled. My father having been born on April 9, 1955, has a birth certificate that identifies his color and race as being "NEGRO." My grandmother, Eloise Marie Harrison having been born on April 4, 1933 has a birth certificate that identifies her color and race as being "NEGRO". My guess is this little boy was also more concerned with  the fact that the most terrible war the world has ever seen was taking place around him. The older I get, the more I realize that it's mostly "whites" who take the most offence at the "racist" terms that they historically created. 

When I worked with a company that was largely black, I asked them which terms they were offended by. 

None objected to being called 'black'. It's a pretty neutral term, heavily dependant on a supportive context to make it racist. 

Some of the older blacks still used 'colored', but it has fallen out of common useage mainly because it's antiquated -- old fashioned-like. It's usually construed as racist only in the overall context of segregation.  

Some were less keen on 'negro', but still used it occasionally. The problem they had was that, culturally, it has taken on a similar (but less intense) meaning as 'Uncle Tom'. 

African-American is acceptable, but it's an awkward term that has its own implications of being racist without seeming racist. "You're American but you're also AFRICAN-American". As if to remind everyone that they're in a special class; African first and American by convenience or grace. 

And despite what the media and it's lauded Rap stars would have people believe, I can't think of any of the blacks I worked with who did not despise the use of 'n-----'. That one, hands down, is taken as an insult. Even when used among themselves, it's insulting. Albeit, arguably less than insulting than when a non-black uses it.

www.flickr.com/photos/9688250@N02/ The problem is that uninformed younger people equate "Negro" with the "n word." For many, many years, people of African descent used the term Negro to refer to themselves, and, in fact, a few older ones still do today. The 2010 U.S. census included a category "Negro" for the very reason some people still use this term to identify themselves. The term almost certainly started in the early 18th century when Spanish and Portuguese traders referred to Africans as being negro (which means black in both Spanish and Portuguese). I do not believe the term as originally used was meant to degrade people of African origin. Where it becomes "racist" was when slave owners and traders in the Southern U.S. assimilated the word to "nigra". This and the "N Word" became synonymous with the black slave. Although the blacks in the South were freed by Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, they never were truly "freed" from the prejudice and injustice they received mostly in the South. So, derogatory terms used by some Southerners for them continue to this day to be considered offensive. However, the terms "Negro" and "Colored" were never really considered by most African Americans to be offensive until the late 1960's. IMHO, the "N Word" is offensive because it is forever linked to the image of the slave, the subservient being under the White man. If black people want to use the word to refer to one another, that is up to them. I wish it would go away, but it won't. And I don't think we should ever forget that it was not that many years ago that blacks were routinely lynched for the only "crime" of being born with dark skin. We should never forget that in the 1920's, there were still millions of members of the KKK who viewed blacks as subhuman. Even today, we have people such as Ted Nugent referring to our President as being subhuman. It's sad and it is sick. But, there is absolutely nothing wrong with the use of Negro in the title of this photo since it was titled in 1942.

I believe this picture was taken in Memorial Stadium. I don't think Nebraska had a dedicated track facility prior to 1975 when Ed Weir Track was built.

Under the east section of the stadium there is a small track.  They had meets there during inclement weather.   I remember going there with my father.  As I recall, they did everything but pole vault due to the low ceiling.  Its been about 10 years since I've been in the "mushroom gardens" as it was called.    Before Ed Weir, they ran outdoor meets inside the stadium proper.   You'd run straight along the east and west side of the football field, then run around the sweeping curves at the north and south ends.   There used to be storage areas on the the north and south ends of the east and west stadiums.  These areas stored the hurdles and gear the meets needed.  I remember seeing javelins, shots, discus, being stored in the equipment room in the north stadium building that had the clock on it.  That building is gone now.
Here is a little additional information on the "mushroom gardens", and the rec center that replaced them. media.www.dailynebraskan.com/media/storage/paper857/news/...

Route 74 seems to end around Peebles, OH. Mt Gilead is on the 1942 map in its present location and does not appear to have Route 74 going through it. I could be wrong, but I think this picture would have to have been taken between Cincinnati and Peebles if it was taken along Route 74 in Ohio in 1942 or 1943. In 1962 Ohio Route 74 was rename Ohio Route 32 when Interstate 74 was built. There are several sections in Cincinnati still called "Old State Route 74"

C.A. Long
Submitted by Charles David Long on Fri, 11/27/2009 - 11:57pm.

C.A. Long was my great-grandfather. The building in the photo was constructed in 1896 for the International Order of Odd Fellows. The Lodge used the top story for its meetings and rented the ground floor. Charles Anderson Long (1859-1939) moved his grocery business from Williamsburg, Ohio, to Mount Orab in 1931.

The business before C.A. rented it in 1931 was a shop that assembled horse buggies (see second photo below). Charles rented the building for his grocery business. His son Julius Paul Long had taken over the grocery in 1939 after C.A.'s death. My father, J.P. Long Jr., bought the grocery in 1968 and continued the business on the corner of 74 & 68 until 1972, when it moved north of town on State Route 68. It closed in 1988.

The Marvel was the movie theater in town about one block south on Route 68. It is now being used as the local Masonic Lodge. Route 74 was renamed State Route 32 and then eventually Tri-County Road. The IOOF building was sold when the Lodge closed (1990s?) and is now being used as a women's clothing store.

The building is still standing on the north-west corner of "Main and High" in Mt. Orab Ohio.
You can use Google street view to see it here: 39.027888,-83.919853
"Main ST" is now Tri-County Road as mentioned by a relative of the original store owner above.
The building can be recognized by the distinctive half-round windows and now-boardedup stone archway along the East side.

Glad you're enjoying the photos!  Because the title does not appear in brackets, it is transcribed from an original source.  Generally, a title is transcribed from the original picture, or from a photographer's logbook or negative jacket. If the picture carries no caption a title is devised from another source and displayed in brackets. Devised titles are written by Library staff, or they might come from a published book illustration or a former owner.

What is a company housing settlement?

A company housing settlement is when a company provides houses for their workers.  This was pretty common in Puerto Rico before the '50s, especially in the sugar-cane industry.  There is a great example of a CHS in the Central Aguilar Sugar Company.  There were houses, schools, churches, grocery stores, an independent plumbing system, etc. within the grounds of the factory.  They were pretty much independent towns, usually divided between American "whites" and Puerto Rican "blacks".  In fact, in Aguilar, the American houses were painted white while the Puerto Rican houses were painted gray, to tell them apart.

This is not the coast of Puerto Rico but downtown Christiansted St Croix.  The point in the distance with the white structure is Ft Louise Augusta.  The bandstand stands today although the area that was for many years a parking area has now been reclaimed by the NPS and is grass.  The large tree (a tamarind) is blocking Fort Christiansvaern.  If you would like further evidence there is a photo of Transfer Day celebrations the following year (1942) which shows the same bandstand after some white paint had been applied.

rigglord,
Glad you're enjoying the photos! Because the title does not appear in brackets, it is transcribed from an original source. Generally, a title is transcribed from the original picture, or from a photographer's logbook or negative jacket. If the picture carries no caption a title is devised from another source and displayed in brackets. Devised titles are written by Library staff, or they might come from a published book illustration or a former owner.

Notice how the walls are lined with cardboard.

I keep coming back to photo's of homesteader Jack Whinery and his family. Yes the dugout interior walls are covered with cardboard - The dugout itself is made of large logs - Not sure what the roof is. I don't know if Jack dug the space-cut the tree's-hauled the rocks for the 'foundation'-not sure what the roof is made of - or see any bathroom (i'm sure was outdoors. Look at the tenacity/hardness of his face. The mother has a hard worn edge - 5 children-keeping the homestead up not to mention I'll bet she was out in the fields with the children doing their part to help. I also got a sense of community from these photo's. They may not have had "the best" but the children look relatively healthy. They went to school-church-worked-played. It feels like a family unit that worked/played together during extremely tough times. They worked hard and brought the family together to enjoy the fruits of their labors. Wonder if any of the children still survive? Did they stay in the area? Did they grow up and get as far away as they could? Was there more going on in that dugout than what we think we see thru the lens of the camera?Would be fascinating to hear their life story.

I saw this first at Shorpy. "The House that Jack built" and at that site there is much more information about the family. What a great family shot - poor or not, the family looks healthy and that was an achievement back then.
Poor things, my we have come a long way!

The Whinery Children- The boys: Oldest boy is A.J. Whinery, baby boy is Lawrence Whinery. The girls: Oldest girl is Laura Whinery, Wanda Whinery is in white, and Velva Whinery is in pink. Placing a tag of vaquero or vaqueros on this photo is not historically accurate. The photo is in New Mexico, ( I live in New Mexico), and those are cowboys. But, vaqueros pre-date the cowboy. Vaqueros date to early 1600's. Cowboys were an product of the Americans 1850 arrival in the Southwest and adopting, then changing, the vaquero culture that existed.  The vaquero culture used specific equipment, lassos of 120 feet intead of the cowboys 60 foot lassos. The vaquero were on open ranges while cowboys fenced the ranches. I can assure you the photo was on a fenced ranch. And those are not vaqueros. There are some that are trying to keep the vaquero culture alive, but they are rare.

as per the shoes....well, this is just coming out of the depression..many folks from that time talk about only getting one pair of shoes a year at christmas and these would be used for shcool and church only..not going to the fair...though they do seem to be in their sunday best even though alot of the material comes from the large flour sacks of the time period....even a pllowcase was used to make one girls outfit.....there are a few store bought items there too..
the ads are because they are at a fair..not at school..

No one wearing glasses either !
The lady in the middle of the photo (light green scarf and dark red sweater appears to be wearing glasses.

The absence of obese people and people wearing glasses is due to a harder way of life that is almost unimaginable today. Food was scarce back then and the work was very, very hard. People simply had less available time to eat. I am sure many of these people needed glasses but couldn't afford them, or, equally as likely they simply did without them. The priorities in their lives, the things that were important to these people, were much more basic then than in today's world.

@brock6051: People work just as hard today as they did back then, but back then people ate only during meal times and only when they were hungry, it wasn't just hard work or lack of food or lack of time to eat. The obesity epidemic began in the late 1980's, early 1990's, caused by many factors non-existent 40, 50, 60 years ago, like food addiction and food as therapy and ginormous, super-sized portions at restaurants, movie theaters, etc.

I graduated high school in 1980, and there was only ONE fat student in my entire graduating class. In fact, I think that person was the only fat person in the entire student body.  Everybody was skinny, boys and girls, like these people in these photographs, and we had plenty of food back in the 1980's.

Check out the photographs from the 1970's in the U. S. National Archives photostream.  EVERYBODY was skinny, and I don't remember any kind of a food shortage in the 1970's either.

Look at this group of slender, young women from the early 1970's:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/usnationalarchives/7461393070/in/set-72157630329782642]

And this group of young people:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/usnationalarchives/7455138962/]

Something you'd never see today, but back then, this was normal.

koda24: Sorry about the confusion in the different dates that display with this photo.  You've spotted one of the anomalies that happens when historical images are loaded to Flickr in batches. 

The date "1940 Oct.&quot (in the description on the left) refers to when the photographer probably snapped the shutter. It's the date that came with the original photo caption.

The year that displays when searching for photos and under "additional information" (on the right) reflects the single year we were limited to while loading an entire set of photos as a batch.  We picked "1940" to indicate the closest decade. The month "Jan." also comes from the batch loading settings.

We'll keep looking for a way to synch up the real date and the batch-loading date.

Wonderful shot, I am a native New Mexican and this is great to see.  I can relate to how still one had to stand to get a shot back then, while looking into our bright sunshine with no shades.

After her work on the farm was done, she then had to do her chores in the house and get the children ready for bed.Quilts like these were usually made in the few remaining hours before bedtime and on a sunday(day of rest?). So this probably took a couple of years to complete.(speaking as a quiltmaker who also has to fit sewing into a busy day).If she had a machine, it may have taken less,but it's quite an accomplishment -and she's obviously very proud of it.

Hello,

I am sure you are very busy and probably won't see this, but none-the-less I want to inform you that seeing these pictures of Pie Town has inspired me to create a presentation for a class project focusing on it, and my family and I are going to go visit it in a few weeks. We've lived in NM for more than eight years and my parents were visiting it many years before I was born, and we've never been there before! Can you believe it?

Thank you for uploading these images, as they have been so fun to look at and provided me much inspiration! Imagine, losing your income (and everything else) in the Dust Bowl, and packing up your family to head over to The-Middle-Of-Nowhere, New Mexico, to try to start all over.  Look at us now!  We could all learn a lesson from these hard working folks!

~A.M.

(PS- I will be sure to take lots of pictures while I'm there!)

The Whinery Children- The boys: Oldest boy is A.J. Whinery, baby boy is Lawrence Whinery. The girls: Oldest girl is Laura Whinery, Wanda Whinery is in white, and Velva Whinery is in pink. Velva's middle name is Mae, and her obituary is here. It says she was born in Adrin, TX, Lawrence and Wanda passed away before Velva, and as far as I know Laura and A.J are still alive. At the time of Velva's passing, Laura lived in Clifton, CO with the married name Murray, and Jack lived in Clifton. It doesn't say which of the many Cliftons it is, so I am guessing it is Clifton, TX. A married name was not listed for Wanda, so I assume she never married. While I found the obit. on the internet, I found the names of the other children while in Pie Town the other day. It was a photographer's dream!
Miss Mikaela, that's really cool to know their names and fates.  I appreciate your posting all that.
Happy to share, Ms Penny! I was so elated to find the information myself, and knew others had to be wondering some of the same things I was about the family.

Cassie's Grandma-
Jack (First name: Abrim. Second name: Jackson. Surname: Whinery) was born on June 11, 1907. That would have made him 33 years old when this picture was taken. I have looked and looked, but have yet to find the birth-date of Edith (First name: Laura. Second name: Edith. Maiden surname: Evans. Married surname: Whinery), but I do agree that she was most likely younger than Jack, as was almost always the case in that time.  Can you believe it, after this was taken they had two more children together (Meriam Marcie Whinery and Floyd M. Whinery)? Albeit they still only had six living with them, as Lawrence died in 1944

Jack Whinery

Velva M. Kosakowski of Grand Junction died on May 27, 2007 at age 75.

She was preceded in death by her mother and father, her brother, Lawrence Whinery and sister, Wanda Whinery.

www.shorpy.com/node/1595 Provided this info Information about the Whinery children Submitted by Alexandra on Mon, 04/27/2009 - 10:08pm. I was in Pie Town a few days ago and managed to find the name of all the Whinery children. The oldest girl is Laura; Velva (middle name "Mae") is in pink, and Wanda is in white. The eldest boy is A.J, and the baby boy's name is Lawrence. I know for certain that Wanda, Velva, and Lawrence have died. Wanda was born in Adrin, Texas on August 29, 1931 and died on May 27, 2007 at the age of 75. She was married twice, to Clifford Miller on Nov 4, 1956, and she had four children, two boys and two girls, and Chester Kosakowski, age 81, on Oct 31, 2005. In her obituary it says that Wanda and Lawrence preceded her in death, Wanda likely unmarried as they referred to her as Wanda Whinery instead of with a married name. It also said that Laura and A.J. survived her, so unless they have passed away in the meantime, Laura is living in Clifton, Colorado, with the married name Murray, and A.J is living in Dayton (it doesn't say which of the 23 Daytons in the US, so I'm guessing it is Dayton, TX) I talked to a man who lived in Pie town for all of his life, and he said that he doesn't think the Whinery home is still there. Neither is the Farm Bureau building that the children went to school in. On the other hand, one of the other school buildings is still there and being re-stuccoed and made into a residential home. Their current public schools are in Datil and Quemado, none in Pie Town. The current population of Pie Town is approximately 60 people, and the Pie-O-Neer has better pie than The Daily Pie.

I need to comment on the whole collection now.  I was a toddler when these pictures were made.  The FSA which paid the photographers to document America at that time was a "New Deal" program of FDR.  I remember when he died.  I also remember when JFK was assassinated  The mood of the country was the same both times.  I think the closest event in recent times is the death of Princess Diana.  I mention that so the younger generation will have an inkling of what I am trying to express.  These pictures portray our country at a time when the economy was so far worse than it is now that there is really no comparison.  The reason why our current economic plight is not as terrible as the Great Depression is entirely due to radical changes initiated by FDR.  When the Great Depression struck the country toward the end of the Hoover administration, there was no agency in the federal government available for assistance of any kind.  It was a purely capitalilstic economy, and except for a few weak and outdated laws passed to restrict monopolies, there was no government regulation of anything.  Likewise, there was no government encouragement of anything, either.  There was very little government at all, which sounds like the current idealism of what is called The Tea Party.  It is also the idealism of large corporations.  

The very existence of these pictures is a direct result of the New Deal programs of FDR.  Besides this beautiful collection, there are thousands of black-and-white prints  made all over the country, many of them now famous icons.  America needs to look back to see what kind of country we had before FDR before we decide to go back to those "good old days."  These pictures are a good way to do that looking.

Title: Buffalo Gals

Now, this is a 'square dance'! The four couple you can see [including the hand] are in a circle, doing a 'grand right and left', where the men go in one direction around the 'square' of four couples and the women the other, given each other alternatively their right and left hand as they pass in the opposite direction [see the arm and hand directly at the back of the photo]. This is probably as the dancers have been around the circle and met their partners, where they would 'swing'.

I thought I would try to bring back some of the colour. This one is faded, and has shifted to purple, and I have a feeling that the film stock used was not great, or in some way unstable, but I've done what I can. As to film stock, for some reason, this data is not included in LOC's records for any of its colour images from this period, which is too bad, because it can be crucial to restoration efforts. www.flickr.com/photos/theonemacduff/5547531094/in/album-7...
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/theonemacduff], most of the FSA/OWI slides are Kodachrome. They are stored off-site in cold storage so it's not easy to quickly check each one.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/jon_loc]  Yup, I figured that was the case, based on work I've done on others, but it's nice to have confirmation. But this one was so badly faded, shifted so much towards purple, that my thought was that somehow the flash being used was not a good balance for Kodachrome, that the faux colour was baked into the slide from the moment the shutter was tripped. Unfortunately, I don't know enough about early flash bulbs or the 1930s chemistry of Kodachrome to figure it out.

BTW, while the slides were scanned at 3600dpi, by the time you crop away the slide mount area, you're down to 3000-3100dpi, and personally, I would say that a 35mm slide shot through good glass – as these were – should be scanned at a minimum of 4800dpi. This is about enough so that you can begin to make out grain in the image. The larger file size also allows you greater freedom to sharpen, if you want to, and gives smoother colour transitions, and better shadow detail. Jest sayin'.

Interesting beams, they are formed concrete, evident by the indents along the sides where you can see the granules from the mix, and caused by the boards in the form.

I disagree. Those are wood timbers. Concrete beams of that length were not in use at that time. Large trees were still available to make such long beams. Since the picture was taken in 1939 or 1940, the building would have been from a much earlier era.
it's a tough call...looks like you can see the indents from boards in a form but anyhoo...the Roman colisseum was constructed of concrete CK42.

Look at the first beam in the larger version and you'll see obvious signs of forming over the support where the edges of boards are seen and gravel texture peaks out on the sides.  There are also dings in the too perfect corners of the top edges.

The length of the concrete beams was why I thought this was so interesting for its time period.  Most of the wood has been removed from the building, and beams of that size in that length would be too valuable to leave.

It is a great place to get naughty.

The ladder may still be in place from the process of making the haystack.  A well-made, evenly shaped haystack, with the hay firmly packed into place from the ground up, could withstand most winds without damage.  

I am curious about the oblong shape of this haystack.  The shape is unlike the round haystacks that were usually made inside a large cage .  Yet,  the sides of this haystack are quite straight and it's very tall so if it was done freeform, it's a masterpiece.

And here I thought they were putting the finishing touches on the country drive-in theater :)

There are enough bulges here and there that I'd believe it was free-form - what strikes this city-boy's eyes is that is a lot of hay to have stacked outside without any cover?

I'm a generation younger than this photo, but I grew up on a ranch in northern Nebraska where we made haystacks.   The haystacks were kept outside, and they were shaped to shed water.  If they were used during the first winter after they were made, rotting of the hay from moisture was minimal.  It wouldn't have been practical to keep all the hay inside because such a great quantity of hay was harvested each year to see the cattle through the long winter.  I think this was probably true in 1940 in Colorado also.  Also, keep in mind that the annual rainfall isn't that much in Colorado.  The main reason to keep hay inside is to avoid water damage.

This looks a lot like the haystacks my father made when I was a kid. He had a large rectangular form on wheels that resembled a large cage with vertical bars on the side where the entire back section butterflied open to allow pulling the form away once the hay was stacked inside - leaving a nice rectangular stack that very much resembles the one in this photo. The form is very similar to the one in this photo from John Means Whatever's photostream

Prairie Bluestem is right on. Each area of the country had their own system of haying. This stack could have been  put up with either an overshot or beaver slide stacker. After the stack reached a certain height the stacker was drug several feet and continued, although it does appear to have been stacked in distinct layers.

One reason for the heigth was to get more tons protected with the smallest surface area, leaving little to the elements. If you go by the Haythorn Ranch at Arthur, NE you can see this still done with horses.

I want to amend my comments on the hay stack listed just above. With the above mentioned stackers the guys on top had to spread the hay with forks to the end and edges of the stack. It took some doing, but but with care the sides could be kept straight.

This is one reason why I LOVE old photographs! I take it this was taken in summer, instead of just seeing the season, you can almost feel the heat of summer coming off this picture, the colour is so vibrant, it`s hard to explain. Lovely picture! Thank You!

A co-worker mentioned that we have 16mm movie footage showing hay being stacked in the 1940s on the Ninety-Six Ranch in Nevada, with a locally made derrick. Accompanied by explanations and new technology videotaped in the 1980s by the Library's American Folklife Center. To check it out: memory.loc.gov/ammem/ncrhtml/crmenu3.html (Searching this American Memory collection using the word "hay" gets you a lot of stills too: memory.loc.gov/ammem/ncrquery.html )

As Colorado Kid 42 says, this could be stacked by folks who knew what they were doing. It is a larger scale of what my father did on a hayrack pulled by horses in the fields of our NH hill farm. Placing each pitched-on fork-full of hay in the right place and then treading it down kept it on for the sometimes bumpy ride to the barn. Then, the hay was unloaded with a pitchfork and pitched into the haymows in the barn. Very hot work in a humid NH summer.

As a kid in the 60's our family drove from Boise to Emmett on every-other-Sunday to grandma's house along the old freeze out road.  There were birds' nests in the bluffs and a gas station where dad would stop and buy us Cheetos and grape soda.  On the way home at night we'd pass by the drive-in movie and I remember seeing Jane Fonda in Barbarella up on the screen.

This picture looks very familiar with the scenes that i saw when i was with a group driving to California for a church conference.  The mountainous road really impresses me because it seems like it takes lots of hard work to build roads through mountains.  The fact that they were doing this before 1941 impresses me even more.

Yes, Old Freezeout still exists. A faster less curvy road is used for most traffic, but you can still take the Old Freezeout route alternate.  Like t8rtart I road over it with my grandfolks many times. We preferred to explore the old road with all it's pioneer history. There used to be a monument to pioneers on teh road, but it was moved to Emmett Idaho to preserve it. There were a lot of stories of adventure and outlaws on old freezeout hill from folks in Emmett.

I f you look to the right and above old freeze out road you will see a cut in the hill side.  That is the ramainder of the Old Bayse road which was build to bypass the original steep freeze out road, which went down one of the steep ridges into the valley.  Bayse built this road with less of a grade so he could get lumber out of the Payette River Valley, (Emmett-where he had a saw mill) over to Boise.  As you drive the 'old freezeout road' you can see the rest of the ramains of the Bayse road as it descends into the valley.  

The original freezeout road was part of the (Tom) Goodale cutoff from the Oregon Trail,  in an attempt to shorten the distance from  Boise to Payette.

Old school manual labor!  So many questions I'd like to ask these two...
Would those be telephone or telegraph lines?
the hi res LOC scan of this is soft.

They are telephone lines, rural telephone companies were often co-ops financed by guaranteed loans through the Rural Electrification Administration.  Thanks to FDR.
(A telegraph line was a single wire, the earth was the return side of the circuit.  Telephone lines were pairs of wires.  Up to ten subscribers could share one pair -- a party line.  It looks like about fifteen pairs on these poles, so that could be as many as 150 telephones, but was probably about 50 on party lines and five to ten expensive private lines)
Amazing landscape; colors are so vivid!  I'd have never guessed this was possible for photography of this era.

Power line on the horizon.  If this is Greene County, Georgia, the poles and wires belong to the members of Rayle EMC (Electric Membership Cooperative).  The Frankliln D. Roosevelt Administration initiated a lot of new government agencies to rescue the country from the Great Depression.  Among those programs was the Rural Electrification Administration which was empowered to provide or guarantee low intererst loans to Electric Membership Cooperatives.  No 'for profit' electric utility would take the loss of building the grid where only one or two subscribers were available per mile of line.  The EMCs saved the day and electrified all of that part of America that would still be in the dark today without the foresight of one of our greatest presidents.
The trouble with Greene County is that it has no landmarks, like Brasstown Bald.  So you can't tell which way you are looking in this picture, or even for certain that you are in Greene County.
I wonder if this isn't an old plantation house.  Notice the columns on the front porch.  The brick chimneys were originally stuccoed.  And there's an enormous magnolia tree in the side yard.

It is fascinating to see the Georgia State flag in this photograph.  It was often suggested, during the fierce debates in the late 1990's and 2000 about removing the Confederate battle emblem from the Georgia State flag, that to remove the battle emblem was to reject history.  This photo is a good reminder of the reality of the situation.  (The Confederate battle emblem was added to the Georgia State flag only in 1956; if anything, the current flag, adopted in 2003, is actually closer to the historical flag, based on the Stars and Bars, as seen in this photo, than was the battle emblem flag adopted in 1956.)

Its October according to the info above not summer. The month of October would be a slack time for ag workers in 1939 since the cotton crop would be slowly maturing without the plant steroids we have today. Its also the time of least rainfall. Cotton picking done by hand would start in the next month or so, I believe. The creek could be Wasp Lake which is an ancient Yazoo River channel. Or perhaps Afchafalya Bayou.

To the seeker without frontiers: The picture has the status of “no known copyright restrictions,” in this case because the photo was made by the U.S. federal government, which are not eligible for U.S. copyright protection. You can find out more about the “no known copyright restrictions” status on this Flickr page: www.flickr.com/commons/usage/. We also offer information in our rights overview, “Copyright and Other Restrictions That Apply to Publication/Distribution of Images: Assessing the Risk of Using a P&P Image”—sometimes there are other types of rights to consider, in addition to copyright so best to review this as well. The Library of Congress is generally not in a position to grant or deny permission to publish images from its holdings because in most cases it does not hold rights to the images.

To those being sarcastic about no litter on the stream banks, one of the boys is sitting on an old tire. I doubt he dragged it there just for a seat. I'd also be willing to bet that if you were to find a house along this stream, there would be plenty of litter. In rural West Virginia where I grew up, people dumped their household trash behind the house, usually in a stream. I'd go wading in the stream that ran beside my grandma's house looking for old bottles, blue mason jars, stoneware jugs, and other "treasures" that people had tossed out in decades past.

Aside from the grubby hat worn by the older girl in the previous cropped version of this scene, that shot didn't say "poor" to me: the kids were well-scrubbed and their clothes freshly washed. This larger, more expansive photo however tells a much different story.

I suspect the combination of these two photos was a deliberate illustrative effort by the photographer - interesting. The close-up photo said to me, "These people could be part of your community"; this one says "Man, what's up with these people - what happened to them?". The combination of the two photos gives me greater respect for photography as an art form.
What an incredibly beautiful image!
Dressed in rags, living in a crumbling shack, working on a white man's farm, and not a single one can afford a pair of shoes; not much difference between 1840 and 1940.

Remember, this was 1940.  This was before LBJ's "War on Poverty", these people were probably exploited farm pickers who made maybe a few dollars a day.  There were also poor whites who lived that way, too.  You realize there was no Medicaid back then, no Medicare, and Social Security was in its infancy.  But, rest assured these people had no social security.  They worked for cash.  Nothing more.  There were no birth control pills so women had children when they couldn't afford them.  It wasn't their fault any more than the men with whom they shared private moments.  I doubt anyone ever discussed family planning with them.  Children were always considered a blessing.  "The Lord will provide" and all that sort of justification.

This is the caption that Marion Post Walcott included with her photo from 1939 but the actual damage to the vegetation occurred in the late 1800's. The smelting technology of that time did not allow the sulfur dioxide generated by the heating of the ore to be captured. By 1909 the mining companies developed new practices which let them recover the sulfur dioxide and use it in the manufacture of sulfuric acid. 

Reclamation in the Basin began in the 1930's with varying degrees of success initially. By the 1970's new techniques were developed and today most of the Basin has been revegetated.
Except that the tractor is pulling a set of harrows, not a drilling machine. Preparation for planting corn perhaps?
Yup, harrowing to prepare the ground and the planter is way at the upper end of the field [based on an earlier photo].

the implement being pulled is a "disc" or "disc harrow" or "disc cultivator" depending on what part of the country you are from. www.everythingattachments.com/tractor-field-garden-disc-h... A "drill" is used to plant small grain crops in very narrow rows, 3 or 4 inches. Planting corn requires a "corn planter" www.binkleyhurst.com/Sales/kinze_page.htm which is also used to plant soy beans. Currently common planting spacing is corn planted in 30 inch rows and soybeans in 15 inch rows. I was a farm boy from 1950 to 1965 and operated this type of machinery.

Not really. The Basin remained denuded until the acid plant and mining operation went out of business in the late '80's. I grew up there, and it looked just like this till I was out of college in the '80's.

I rode thru there yesterday, 10/13/2013.  The Copper Basin is now very green, and the forest is coming back.  It's going to take generations for the trees to mature, however.  Just don't drink the water.

I just spent 20 minutes scanning Skyline Drive on Google Maps and there are no obvious farms. Unfortunately the resolution of the Google Maps imagery is very low - there were a couple areas that looked interesting but they were blurry blobs close-in.

I live at the northern end of the Skyline Drive. This photo appears to be an aerial view. Without specialized lenses, you could not get this type of photo from the drive overlooks.

in fact, several of the photos in the collection appear to be of surrounding roads, not the Drive itself.

The rail fences in the foreground were typical of the region. They could be built without nails or other fasteners -- typically of chestnut, a native wood plentiful in the Blue Ridge Mountains until a blight wiped it out in mid-20th century.  Haystacks were the common way to harvest hay for animal feed before mechanical balers were invented.  I remember my grandfather and older cousins piling hay with pitchforks on a field too marshy to bring machinery into. The two stacks at the left of this field look like they might have been assembled of cornstalks rather than meadow grass.

My parents owned rental properties and a mobile home park when I was a kid and working alongside my dad doing plumbing, electrical, carpentry, digging ditches, whatever it took, that's what we did.   It's called the real world everywhere except our Hollywood-ized version of America.   Oh, and I turned out just fine.. don't hate my folks for making me do what was needed to get us ahead in the world... I'm a better person for it.

This photo was taken in 1940.  It could easily have been my friends and I in the 1980s.  I picked potatoes in Caribou Maine with exactly the same technology.  They let schools out for 3 weeks at harvest.  I don't think any schools close for harvest anymore.  They use harvesters now.  Harvesters require the workers to ride on the machine and are much more dangerous.   Picking potatoes was hard hard work, and I hated it.  Cold many mornings and sweating by lunch.  But rotten potato fights and riding with friends from field to field in the back of the farmers truck have become treasured memories that always bring a smile to my face.  And I LOVED getting my very own paycheck!

Filmann said....In the U.S.A. the ride was actually called The Bullet. That was before it became ... incorrect .... to call it as such.

************

Actually, the real name for the ride is the "Roll-O-Plane", and it was built by Eyerly Aircraft Company out of Oregon.  "Bullet" is a theme-name given the ride by some carnival companies, but is not the official factory name.  Other rides manufactured by this company were the Loop-O-Plane, Rock-O-Plane, and Fly-O-Plane, amongst others (notice a trend in the names?).  They also built the Octopus, Spider, Monster (still seen at many amusement parks), Sidewinder (updated version of the Roll-O-Plane), Arcoplane, Bulgy-The-Whale, Midge-O-Racer, and Ladybugs rides.  All of their rides, minus the Fly-O-Plane (of which one is still in operation and that's all) and Arcoplane (none left), can still be seen on carnival midways and in amusement parks all over the world.

Maybe I will write it for them.

So I will. "My real name is Ruth, the Ruth from the bible. My stage name is "Sadie The Sinner." Was I ever a child of God? They say God watches over children and fools, I'm no longer a child so I guess that makes me a fool. A foolish woman. The foolish woman Blues, now there would be a good song! We all have stage names, slave names, call it what you will. Blondyene Lane is the real star of the show. I am too old now to be the star of anyhing. But, hidden from the public, I keep my sanity in a old hat box. I keep things I found town after town. I keep buttons I find, they are always losing them here on the mid way and I know how to make a costume. I keep my Dinah Washington records along with a lovely pine cone I found  and a broken sky blue Robins egg I found once near the stage steps. I keep them all under my bed out back. If I can keep those things I just might make it through another night of  this! Just let me hear Dinah Washington sing Me and my Gin, just another night. Just one more night of this!

Jack Delano travelled to Puerto Rico in 1941 as a part of the FSA project. This trip had such a profound influence on him that he settled there permanently in 1946.

With his wife Irene (a second cousin to fellow photographer Ben Shahn) he worked in the Community Division of the Department of Public Education producing films, for many of which Delano composed the score.[4] Delano also directed Los Peloteros, a Puerto Rican film about poor rural kids and their love for baseball. The film remains a classic in Puerto Rican cinema. He died 1997 in Puerto Rico.

This is more than likely the Singer Family barn (as in Singer Sewing).  My Mother remembers the grain silos very well and knew the barn and the property.  My grandparents (and my mother) lived next door to the Singer Family (our property ran against theirs).  My grandparents are in the foreground and attended the auction.  What is being sold off are the tools.  The cows left well before the tools were disseminated.

I love how people think old photos are photoshopped. They've probably never seen properly exposed slide film before. It just shows how people have lowered their expectations because of digital and why I am shooting more and more film.

Have to agree with Wetmogwai and Erin - why someone would want to display their ignorance with stupid notes on a beautiful Kodachrome like this is beyond me. Just plain dumb. 
Best thing about colour reversal? You release the shutter & the work is done - no need to muck about in the darkroom or at the 'puter. All you need is a light box, a lupe and a big waste basket for all the also-rans.

FYI - My "Photoshoped" note was totally tongue-in-cheek! Duh.. this is a Library of Congress photo that is OBVIOUSLY (at least to me) the original scanned in photo created pre-digital... Sorry for the confusion! I will add a smiley face to hopefully emphasize the jest!

1 Hancox Street (the house in the middle of the photo, right by the water) is the house we now own! It's only been in my family for the past 8 years or so. According to the granddaughter of the original owners, the house used to be a fish and chips restaurant. During the Hurricane of 1938, it was one of the only houses still standing. There is a picture of the house with the entire bottom gutted out. To rebuild, the owners made sure the walls were reinforced with concrete and steel, to prevent any future damage to the vulnerable side facing the ocean. Also, photographer Rollie McKenna also lived there!

Whoever wrote this caption was used to Southern tobacco harvesting where the entire plant was cut, leaves and all , and hung to dry.  Connecticut Shade was harvested leaf by leaf ("Primings" - usually 3 leaves at a time as they matured; 5-6 "primings" a season) and the leaves dried.  The photo shows end of the harvest; the shade cloth sidewall has been taken down & the plants knocked down to rot into the soil as a green fertilizer.  The shade top cloth will come off next and be recycled as sidewall the next season.  You can see that the pole rows haven't been cut down yet - the plants are still pushing the top cloth up - they had to be cut by hand w/ machetes.

There is a 1961 film, Parrish, that I saw on AMC last month. I knew about the Connecticut tobacco but did not know the shade process.  The movie is more of a soap opera but is great about describing the process and area.

William Joseph Hill, one of the best known pop songwriters of that time lost his battle with alcohol abuse and died of heart failure. On Sept 24th, 1940, he performed at the Golden Gate Exposition in San Francisco. Also performing at that show; Irving Berlin, Hoagy Carmichael, and Johnny Mercer. Three months later, on Christmas Eve, he died of heart failure in a Boston hotel room. He was only 42.

The absurdity of the caption is frightening. You don't MAKE natural gas. These tanks held manufactured gas. The gas was a by-product of the coke manufacturing process. Natural gas was quite rare in New England in 1941. What few pipelines that existed carried oil and not much of it.

This is the corner of School and Main Streets in Brockton, Mass. I actually ate in Sylvia Sweet's Tea Room, which (though its name changed) was still active as a coffee shop at least into the Sixties. The buses from Boston (i.e., the Eastern Mass Street Railway buses from Ashmont Station at the end of what is now the Boston's Red Line) used to end their runs here. (They began their return trips from here, too.) The shot is looking north along Main Street. There was a big bank where the clock is, and a couple of blocks further along (just out of the frame) is where the Brockton Enterprise-Times was, where for many years my mother wrote articles for the social pages. If you follow rrsafety's advice and go to maps.live.com, go down to "street level." You'll see a bus rounding this very corner and this building. Diagonally across the street is a building with a rounded facade. That used to be Kresge's (precursor to today's K-Mart), and where I worked for two years in the Fifties in high school. By the way, one of the sons of George L. Wainwright (whose law office is above Sylvia Sweet's) is president of my class (1959) at Brockton High. He is himself a lawyer.

Other Flickr users beat me to it, but one of the readers of my Brainiac column in the Boston Globe wrote to say: "The Massachusetts Street Scene photo with Sylvia Sweets Tea Room was taken in Brockton, MA. This building is at the corner of School St. and Main Street, AKA The Bixby/Homebank Building." I've also learned that:
* Sylvia Sweet's "was located one block from the Brockton Police Station and often supplied food for prisoners." -- Tom Monaghan
* Sylvia Sweet's was on "the northeast corner of Main St. and School St, looking north on Main St. My mother was coincidentally named Sylvia, and she liked to get a dish of ice cream there while shopping." -- Joe Tomaselli
* Sylvia Sweet's "was there for a long time and had soda fountain and luncheon menu. The Dayos family from Brockton owned and operated it for many years." -- Fred Mullins
* Sylvia Sweet's "was owned and operated by a man whose last name was Dayos. I don't know his first name, but he lived with his wife and three (I believe) children on a street off West Elm Street on Brockton's west side. His son, Nicholas Dayos, was a friend of mine during our elementary, junior high, and high school days. He was killed a few years ago in a car crash. I am 75, and he was perhaps two years older. A guy who would give you the shirt off his back, as the saying goes, if you needed it." -- John J. Mullins [Any relation to Fred? -- ed.]
* Sylvia Sweet's "was a popular lunchroom, especially for people waiting for buses at the nearby bus stop." And: "The street floor was also the location of a popular department store, McCarthy's, and a jewelry store.The upper floors contained mainly law offices. In the 70s the building was being remodeled for housing when a fire destroyed it. The building was later rebuilt following its original design. It currently contains apartments on its upper floors and commercial space on the street floor." -- Robert Corey
* "In the early 1950s we used to take the bus from Hanson, shop in the wonderful Brockton downtown, and get a snack at Sylvia Sweet's before taking the bus back home. How the city has changed. No more bus, no more Sylvia Sweet's." -- Carolyn Galambos
* This same photo was "misidentified in the book, 'America: A Celebration,' by Martin Sandler." -- David Gain

As a kid I watched the victory parade for Rocky Marciano from the window of my father's law office on the second floor.  As the law office of George L. Wainwright expanded, more windows were lettered in gold leaf, as was the parctice in those days.  The upper floors were mostly law offices and insurance agencies.  The lobby and stairway were marble and brass.  All of the office doorways had glass transoms.  The ground floor was all retail.  One of the stores, McCarthy's, was owned by a couple who perished in the famous Coconut Grove fire in Boston, but the business continued for many years thereafter.  The Eastern Mass Street Railway buses stopped at this corner coming from all directions and leaving at the direction of a "starter" who was stationed there all day long.  Not shown to the right was one of several "Frye's Cigar Stores" located in the downtown area.  -  Attorney William Wainwright

The law firm of Wainwright and Wainwright (via the link above) gives George L. Wainwright's name (1901-1996). Wainwright and Wainwright is now a three-generation family firm in Brockton.

Sylvia Sweets Tea Room
My father, John Dayos started Sylvia Sweets Tea Room in the early thirties.  He had worked for many years at Liggett’s Drug Store across the street as a “Patent Man” but after getting married in 1929, he soon decided he wanted to own his own business as so many Greek immigrants did.   He was a success story in that he had sold newspapers as a young immigrant boy on the same corner –School and Main Street many years before.  He and his business partners started out to open a candy store.   One of the stories I remember was that they bought a gas stove.  A lady came out to demonstrate the stove and suggested they could boil chicken and serve sliced chicken sandwiches, and chicken salad sandwiches.  This lady was Ruth Wakefield – later the owner of the well known Toll House Restaurant and the originator of the Toll House Cookie or the Chocolate Chip Cookie.  The sliced chicken sandwich was a specialty until the Sylvia Restaurant closed in the late 60’s.   Mrs. Wakefield always remembered my father by name whenever we went to the Toll House for special dinners.

The whole family at one time or another worked at “Sylvia’s”--my mother Effie, my brother Nick, my sister Dorothea and myself, Elaine.  Sylvia’s is often remembered in the Brockton newspaper ‘The Enterprise” column “From our Readers” as a downtown fixture – after the movies, catching a bus to and from the surrounding towns to shop in downtown Brockton,  and a high school hangout.  Sales people and office workers downtown were regulars for lunch and coffee breaks.   I remember well the two ladies who worked at McCarthy’s in the fifties and would come in on Friday night, when the stores were open until 9pm and order Salmon Salad on plain dark bread and my father would enjoy making it extra special for them every week – cut in fours with toothpicks.  .  

In the early fifties downtown Brockton was changing and the business was changing.  My parents decided to remodel the Tea Room which had beautiful mahogany paneling and booths, a marble soda fountain, black glass table tops and oval top mirrors.   It became a modern fifties luncheonette and the name was changed to Sylvia Restaurant and that was when I worked there.  My sister and I started out working by “typing the menus.”  Every day the specials changed and there was a typed menu that was added to the plastic covered Sylvia menu, which had an oval old-fashioned picture of “Sylvia.” (I wish I had a copy of that menu.)  I was told Sylvia was a pretty girl who came over on the Mayflower.  The Greek immigrants wanted to assimilate into American life so they thought the Mayflower was all American.  My mother remembered that when they first opened the Tea Room, she spoke to my father in Greek and he told her to go to the back room to talk to him, as customers didn’t like to hear a foreign language.  She was so upset, she vowed to learn English.  She attended night school and continued for many years, first for English and to become a citizen and then for other classes.  

I vaguely remember when my father still made ice cream for the Tea Room.  Of course we only had Vanilla, Chocolate, Strawberry and Coffee and it was packed in those round Pint or Quart containers.  If  I happened to be there when he was making ice cream,  I would have soft strawberry before it was frozen and this was a special treat.  He told stories that during the depression, they were able to make a good living selling ice cream cones as families could afford a 5 cent ice cream cone.  Of course in those days one never visited someone’s home without a box of chocolates and originally candy was the main focus of the business.

Everyone had his or her special food at Sylvia’s.  Mine was chopped ham and pickle and a strawberry milk shake.  I think I ate that every time I went there in my childhood days.  We would see a “regular” come in and have his coffee, tea or cold drink in front of him before he asked for it.  We had many bachelors that lived in the rooming houses near Main St. who would come in for their dropped eggs on toast for 35 cents in the fifties.  Many of them couldn’t afford much more and occasionally they would have a real lunch or dinner.  We often refered to people by what they ordered, not by their name, since we often didn’t know their name. 

I don’t remember the early days but I heard about them over the years.  Some of the stories reflect the family and community atmosphere of a local downtown tea room.  After the war, my dad gave jobs to many of the service men coming back home – many  went on to become successful Brockton business and professional men, some  to college and some worked at Sylvia’s on and off for years to come.  Romances were also a part of Sylvia’s – waitresses and soda fountain men, customers and of course high school sweethearts.   There were three shifts – the morning crew, the day crew and the night crew worked until 11:00 so that the movie crowd could come in for a snack after the movie.  If you were a “soda jerk” you worked at the end of the counter, pouring Cokes from the red coke machine or making milk shakes, frappes or ice creams sundaes.   Only the more expert counter men worked the sandwich counter.  The waitresses all wore uniforms with those pretty handkerchiefs in their pockets.  

I also remember the Christmas Holiday Season and the Easter season when everyone from Brockton and the surrounding towns came downtown to shop.  We didn’t see much of my dad in those busy times when he often worked 16 hours a day.   He went to work in a suit and tie, with an overcoat and hat, changed his clothes in his “office” always wearing a tie and a white long sleeve shirt with a white bib apron.    I also remember a lovely little lady who was the bookkeeper.  She would come once a week to do the payroll and pay the bills.  Downstairs was the office, the ice cream making machine and the kitchen with the dumb waiter to send up the food.     

My parents, along with countless people who have wonderful memories of Brockton would be so proud to know that downtown Brockton at the corner of School and Main Street and Sylvia Sweets Tea Room was used as an example of a “street in an industrial town in Massachusetts.”  
Elaine (Dayos) Liatsos  8/2008

There is a nostalgia that comes over one looking at old photographs.  Looking at the rare color photo from the 1940's of Sylvia Sweet's Tea Room in Brockton, MA puts a longing in the soul.  It's like there is a yearning for the ability for those doors to be open again and be able to walk through and enjoy a fried clam dinner for only .40cents.  So at today's prices that would be more like $6-$10 but it would be nice. An interest in a time that seemed simpler.  The place looks like it was full of many delicious meals and from the posts I perused after the pictures were posted, this was confirmed.  Many people have enjoyed many good memories there and the color photo was amazing at drawing those memories out to the light of conversation after such a long time in remission.  I looked at the photo of the same corner today on Google map full of traffic passing through.  A couple of people standing on another corner taking an outdoor break.  The opposite corner has a computer repair shop.  Looking at that corner made me wish for Sylvia Sweets to be there again.  That corner in that town looks like it needs something like Sylvia Sweets there again bringing activity, good food, good company and a sense of community back to that corner again.  Wouldn't it be wonderful if Sylvia Sweets could be brought back from the tomes of history and the 1940's to the year 2013 or 2014?

Also there is a title transfer record indicating that Peter Saba sold a lot at this same location to the Tilo Roofing company in 1946.

When this photo was taken, Saba and others like this still had a lot of inventory because we were coming out of the worse decade in history, the Depression.  During that period, nothing was thrown away or discarded, it was used and reused and many considered themselves lucky to get it reused for a third time.  WWII brought the final close to the Depression.  Those of us that are direct descendants of that time, still in old age, tend to save things.
